name: Phuket Town
fun_fact: Fun fact: Phuket's Hokkien noodles come from a restaurant that's been using the same recipe since 1946â€”some restaurants are over 100 years old, still serving the fourth generation of the same family, and locals will fight over which shop makes the best Mee Hokkien.

hero_dishes.name: Hokkien Mee at Mee Ton Poe
hero_dishes.description: Thick egg noodles stir-fried in dark soy sauce with pork, seafood, and Chinese cabbage, topped with a fried eggâ€”smoky, savory, and intensely flavorful
hero_dishes.origin_story: Mee Ton Poe has been Phuket's first-ever Hokkien noodle restaurant since 1946, near the Surin Circle clock tower. Chinese immigrants from Fujian province brought this dish, and the Phuket version became its own thing entirely
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Mee Ton Poe (since 1946), Mee Sapam (since 1952), Ko Yoon, Som Chit (over 100 years old, 4th generation), or Lock Tien (50+ years in business)

hero_dishes.name: Dim Sum at Boonrat Dim Sum
hero_dishes.description: Steamed pork, crab, and shrimp dumplings, seaweed-wrapped pork, and countless varieties from original 1917 Guangzhou recipes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Boonrat has been serving dim sum since 1917â€”yes, over a century. They open at 6am and close at 10am, so locals arrive early or miss out. The recipes came straight from Guangzhou and never changed
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Boonrat Dim Sum (6-10am only!), Hun Dim Sum, or Super Dim Sum & Noodle at Central Festival Phuket

hero_dishes.name: Phuket-Style Hokkien Noodle Soup at Lock Tien
hero_dishes.description: Yellow noodles in rich broth with pork and seafood, topped with a fried eggâ€”the soup version of the stir-fried classic
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lock Tien is like a semi-indoor food court serving Peranakan and Hokkien favorites for over 50 years. Thais from Bangkok consider it a must-eat destination. The noodle soup version shows the Chinese-Peranakan fusion that defines Phuket
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lock Tien (near Phuket Town center)â€”arrive early, locals pack this place

hero_dishes.name: Mee Sapam's Seafood Hokkien
hero_dishes.description: Stir-fried Hokkien noodles with fresh prawns, squid, and fish in dark sauceâ€”excellent ingredients at shockingly cheap prices (around 70 THB)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Mee Sapam opened in 1952 and became famous for using premium seafood while keeping prices affordable. Locals swear by the freshness and value

signature_drinks.name: Chinese Tea at Dim Sum Shops
signature_drinks.description: Hot jasmine or oolong tea served in traditional teacups alongside dim sumâ€”the proper Cantonese way
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Always paired with morning dim sum at places like Boonrat. The tea cuts through the richness of dumplings and helps digestion. Locals linger over multiple rounds

signature_drinks.name: Thai Iced Tea
signature_drinks.description: Sweet, creamy orange tea served over crushed iceâ€”the Thai beverage that tourists know, but locals drink constantly
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Grabbed from street vendors or ordered with Hokkien noodles to balance the salty, savory flavors. The sweetness is essential in tropical heat

food_culture_notes: Phuket's food culture is Chinese-Peranakan, not typical Thaiâ€”expect Hokkien noodles and dim sum, not pad thai
Phuket is a UNESCO City of Gastronomy, recognized for preserving tin-mining-era Chinese immigrant food culture
Hokkien Mee restaurants open early and close when they run outâ€”some only serve breakfast
The fourth-generation Som Chit Restaurant (over 100 years old) proves that family recipes here are sacred

landmarks: Phuket's clock tower at Surin Circle
colors: dark caramel soy sauce on noodles
unique_modern: 6am dim sum queues at century-old Boonrat
Chinese-Peranakan fusion preserved from tin-mining era
